title: Catherine Sourbut Groves
text:
Catherine Ann Sourbut Groves ( Sourbut; born 1967) is a British <a href="Anglican">Anglican</a> priest. Since November 2020, she has served as <a href="Archdeacon%20of%20Lindisfarne">Archdeacon of Lindisfarne</a> in the <a href="Church%20of%20England">Church of England</a>'s <a href="Diocese%20of%20Newcastle">Diocese of Newcastle</a>. She had previously worked in academia and administration at the <a href="University%20of%20Bath">University of Bath</a>, and in parish ministry in the <a href="Diocese%20of%20Bath%20and%20Wells">Diocese of Bath and Wells</a>
Early life and education.
Born Catherine Ann Sourbut, she was brought up in Yorkshire, England. She studied modern languages at the <a href="University%20of%20Bath">University of Bath</a>, graduating with a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">Bachelor of Arts</a> (BA) degree in 1991. As part of her degree she spent a year abroad in Germany, and experienced the <a href="fall%20of%20the%20Berlin%20Wall">fall of the Berlin Wall</a>. She then studied for a <a href="Master%20of%20Science">Master of Science</a> (MSc) degree in social research, which she completed in 1993, and a <a href="Doctor%20of%20Philosophy">Doctor of Philosophy</a> (PhD) degree, which she completed in 1997. Her <a href="doctoral%20thesis">doctoral thesis</a> was titled "Constructions of motherhood: representations and realities of women's experiences as mothers in the former <a href="GDR">GDR</a> under state socialism and capitalism". She remained at the University of Bath to teach in the German section of the Department of European Studies & Modern Languages, before working as a research manager within the Department of Psychology and the School for Health from 2000 to 2007.
She trained for ordination with the <a href="Southern%20Theological%20Education%20and%20Training%20Scheme">Southern Theological Education and Training Scheme</a> (STETS), and then with <a href="Sarum%20College">Sarum College</a> after STETS merged into the college. She continued her studies in theology to complete a <a href="Master%20of%20Arts">Master of Arts</a> (MA) degree.
Ordained ministry.
On 1 July 2007, Sourbut Groves was <a href="ordained">ordained</a> as a <a href="Deacon%23Anglicanism">deacon</a> in the <a href="Church%20of%20England">Church of England</a> by <a href="Peter%20Maurice%20%28bishop%29">Peter Maurice</a>, Bishop of Taunton, during a service at <a href="Wells%20Cathedral">Wells Cathedral</a>. She was ordained as a <a href="Priest%23Anglican%20or%20Episcopalian">priest</a> the following year. She served her <a href="curacy">curacy</a> in three rural village parishes in the <a href="Diocese%20of%20Bath%20and%20Wells">Diocese of Bath and Wells</a> between 2007 and 2011. She then moved to the <a href="benefice">benefice</a> of the Church of St Barnabas, <a href="Bath%2C%20Somerset">Bath</a> and <a href="St%20Peter%27s%20Church%2C%20Englishcombe">St Peter's Church</a>, <a href="Englishcombe">Englishcombe</a> as <a href="priest-in-charge">priest-in-charge</a>, before being made <a href="Vicar%20%28Anglicanism%29">vicar</a> of the same benefice in 2016. She was additionally appointed to the honorary position of <a href="prebendary">prebendary</a> of Wells Cathedral in 2019.
In August 2020, it was announced that she would be the next <a href="Archdeacon%20of%20Lindisfarne">Archdeacon of Lindisfarne</a> in the <a href="Diocese%20of%20Newcastle">Diocese of Newcastle</a>. She was <a href="Collation%20%28religion%29">collated</a> as <a href="archdeacon">archdeacon</a> during a service on 14 November 2020; this service occurred online, as a <a href="Zoom%20%28software%29">Zoom</a> meeting, due to a <a href="The%20Health%20Protection%20%28Coronavirus%2C%20Restrictions%29%20%28England%29%20%28No.%204%29%20Regulations%202020">national lockdown</a> caused by the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">COVID-19 pandemic</a>. She also has a diocese-wide leading role relating to rural parish ministry.
Personal life.
Sourbut Groves is married to Mike Groves. They have two children.
